title: My Child is Bored with Soroban – What Should I Do?
description: Every parent hits this wall: the initial excitement fades. Here's how to handle soroban burnout without forcing or quitting.
imageAlt: Child looking bored with soroban practice

content.intro: My son was SO excited when we started soroban. Three months later, he's dragging his feet. "Do I have to?" every single day. Here's what I learned about motivation, burnout, and keeping the spark alive.

items: **Novelty wore off:** The new thing isn't new anymore
**Hit a plateau:** Progress slowed down, frustration increased
**Comparison:** Sees others doing "easier" things for fun
**Repetition fatigue:** Same types of problems day after day
**External pressure:** Feels like an obligation, not a choice

sections.text: EVERY child goes through this with EVERY skill. Piano, sports, languages, math – the boredom phase is universal. It's how you handle it that matters.

items: ❌ Force longer practice sessions
❌ Threaten or punish for lack of enthusiasm
❌ Compare to other children
❌ Add pressure about progress
❌ Immediately quit and move to something else

sections.text: What to Try First: Reduce, Don't Eliminate
When my son complained, I cut practice from 20 minutes to 10 minutes. That small change made a big difference. He could handle 10 minutes without a battle.

items: Practice at a different time (morning vs evening)
Practice in a different location (couch vs desk)
Practice together (you do problems too)
Make it a race or competition

sections.text: Instead of pushing forward, celebrate what they've already achieved:

items: "Remember when you couldn't do this? Now you can!"
"You're faster than a month ago!"
"Let's show grandma what you learned"

sections.text: Strategy 4: Take a Break (But a Short One)
Sometimes a 1-2 week break is okay. Not months – you'll lose progress. But a short pause can reset motivation.
During a break, casually use mental math in daily life. "Quick, what's 15 + 8?" Keep the brain engaged without formal practice.
My breakthrough came when I started involving my son in real situations:

items: "Help me add up the grocery bill"
"How much change should we get back?"
"Can you calculate the tip?"
"How many more points to reach 1000?"

sections.text: When math had a PURPOSE, his interest returned.
If after trying everything, your child is still miserable for 2+ months, it might be time to pause longer. Better to stop and try again in 6-12 months than to create hatred for math.

faq.question: Is it okay to bribe with rewards?
faq.answer: Small rewards for consistency (not performance) can help. "Practice every day this week, pick a movie Friday." Avoid paying per problem solved.

faq.question: Should I hide my disappointment?
faq.answer: Yes. Your disappointment adds pressure. Stay neutral. "Okay, let's try again tomorrow" is better than sighing and guilt-tripping.

faq.question: Will they regret quitting later?
faq.answer: Maybe. But forced learning creates negative associations that last longer than missed skills. Intrinsic motivation beats forced compliance long-term.

faq.answer: The strategies discussed are primarily designed for children ages 5-12, but many principles can be adapted for different age groups.

faq.question: How long does it take to see results?
faq.answer: Results vary by child, but most parents notice improvements within 2-4 weeks of consistent practice.

faq.question: Can I use these methods alongside school curriculum?
faq.answer: Absolutely! These approaches are designed to complement, not replace, what children learn at school.
